title: 107_hr5461
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regional Comprehensive Emergency Preparedness, Coordination, and Recovery Act of 2002". Congress finds that responders to the 9/11 terrorist attacks required coordination and support from various jurisdictions, including local elected officials, neighboring jurisdictions, and regional, state, federal, and private sector entities due to the large number of agencies involved in emergency response. Regional planning and coordination of response efforts involving various jurisdictions, state, federal, and private sector entities are crucial for effective emergency response to minimize loss of life and property damage. Regional councils of governments, planning commissions, and development districts play a key role in coordinating comprehensive regional plans. Regional councils of governments, planning commissions, and development districts have the accountability and experience to coordinate comprehensive regional plans involving Federal, State, and local governments, the private sector, and other stakeholders for community security. They can ensure the development of coordinated emergency preparedness and recovery plans. Area-wide training and equipment acquisition are also emphasized. Regional councils of government play a crucial role in developing coordinated emergency preparedness and recovery plans involving Federal, State, and local governments, as well as the private sector. The purpose of this Act is to encourage and facilitate the implementation of regional emergency preparedness and coordination plans to enhance preparedness and mitigation efforts. The purpose of this Act is to encourage and facilitate the implementation of regional emergency preparedness and coordination plans to enhance preparedness and mitigation efforts. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "region" refers to a designated multijurisdictional planning area or sub-State district. The term "regional council" denotes a multipurpose association of governments in a planning region. The term "local government" includes any city, county, or township within the United States. The term "State" encompasses any of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, or any territory of the United States. The term "stakeholder" in the context of area development districts includes various entities such as local elected officials, State emergency management agencies, fire and rescue personnel, health professionals, and school representatives. The term "regional plan" refers to a plan developed for emergency preparedness involving various stakeholders including local elected officials, State emergency management agencies, fire and rescue personnel, health professionals, school representatives, college and university representatives, the business community, port and airport officials, utilities, State departments of transportation, and other identified individuals and entities. The term "regional plan" refers to a plan developed for emergency preparedness involving stakeholders such as local officials, emergency management agencies, fire and rescue personnel, health professionals, schools, businesses, ports, airports, utilities, transportation departments, and other identified entities. Requirement to coordinate the development of regional emergency preparedness, coordination, and recovery plans. The regional councils defined in section 3(2) must convene all stakeholders in the region to coordinate emergency preparedness, response, mitigation, and recovery plans. The regional plan should include an assessment of potential targets for destruction and available resources to respond to disasters. The regional emergency preparedness plan must include an assessment of potential targets for destruction, available resources for disaster response, equipment needs, establishment of a regional communication system, secure information repository, and information on response resources. The regional emergency preparedness plan must include a secure information repository with coordination details and information on response resources such as emergency medical facilities, fire, police, and EMT services. The regional emergency preparedness plan should include locations and contacts for fire, police, and emergency medical services, as well as medical facilities, first responders, and essential service stakeholders in the region. Locations and contacts for key military personnel and facilities, existing shelters, schools, colleges, universities, churches, public buildings, major water, and food sources should be included in the regional emergency preparedness plan. Locations of schools, colleges, universities, churches, public buildings, major water and food supplies, water treatment and storage facilities, utilities lines, pipelines, generating facilities, sewer mains, and treatment plants should be included in the regional emergency preparedness plan. The regional emergency preparedness plan should include locations of utilities lines, pipelines, generating facilities, sewer mains, communication facilities, radio and television studios, transmission sites, shortwave radio facilities, and volunteers. The regional emergency preparedness plan should include locations of utilities lines, pipelines, generating facilities, sewer mains, communication facilities, radio and television studios, transmission sites, shortwave radio facilities, volunteers, major bridges, dams, educational facilities, and transportation facilities such as ports and airports. The regional emergency preparedness plan should include the locations and capacities of major transportation facilities, lines, terminals, ports, airports, local and regional transportation routes, at-risk populations, large population concentrations, schedules of major public events, and capacities of venues. The regional emergency preparedness plan should include locations of large population concentrations, schedules of major public events, population statistics, school enrollment numbers, and locations of elderly, infirm, and disabled persons who need special assistance. Additionally, potential targets should be identified, including major concentrations of people. Locations of potential targets include major concentrations of hazardous and biohazard chemicals, fuel depots meeting EPA thresholds, munitions and explosives, and other vulnerable sites. Environmental Protection Agency thresholds, major concentrations of munitions and explosives, potential targets like nuclear power plants, identification of debris disposal locations and health hazards for personnel involved in debris disposal. Planning activities related to these. Planning activities under this section involve analyzing the possibility of a disaster, assessing hazards using Geographic Information Systems, and evaluating potential consequences. The regional plan must be approved by the designated agency's governing body and the Governor. The regional plan for assessing hazards and evaluating consequences of emergencies must be approved by the designated agency's governing body and Governor within 12 months of receiving a planning grant. The plan should be reviewed annually and updated based on threat assessments, trainings, and drills for security purposes. The regional plan required for assessing hazards and emergencies must be approved by the governing body and Governor within 12 months of receiving a planning grant. The information within the plan is only accessible to relevant public and private officials. Computer technology is necessary to secure key resources and critical infrastructure outlined in the plan. Measures must be taken to protect these assets. The regional plan must protect key resources and critical infrastructure by coordinating with various agencies and entities. Recommendations for improving security policies and information sharing are essential for law enforcement and emergency management. The regional plan must protect critical infrastructure by coordinating with various agencies and entities. Recommendations for improving security policies and information sharing are necessary for law enforcement, intelligence, and emergency management within the Federal Government and between representatives in the region. SEC. 5. FUNDING. From allocated emergency preparedness and homeland security funds, not less than three percent must be allocated to the Department of Homeland Security for regional plan preparation, review, and update. Allocations to regions will be based on population, necessary base amounts, vulnerability to catastrophic events, and the presence of significant facilities. Allocations to regions for emergency preparedness and homeland security funds are determined by a formula considering population, base amounts for regional plans, vulnerability to catastrophic events, and significant facilities. Federal funding for local, regional, or State projects must align with regional plans.
